metadata.title: Collections | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: This is an Apple Human Interface Guidelines documentation page about Collections, a UI component that manages an ordered set of content and presents it in a customizable and highly visual layout. The page covers best practices for using collections, platform-specific considerations, and links to related resources and developer documentation.
metadata.copyright: Copyright 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

content.description: A text input field with a filter icon, used to filter the sidebar navigation items

content.text: A collection manages an ordered set of content and presents it in a customizable and highly visual layout.

content.title: Collection Grid Layout Illustration
content.description: A visual representation of a collection view displaying a 2x4 grid of image placeholder items within a rounded rectangle container. The diagram illustrates how collections organize content in a grid pattern with consistent spacing.

annotations.description: A horizontal double-headed arrow on the right side indicating horizontal scroll capability
A vertical double-headed arrow at the bottom indicating vertical scroll capability

content.narrativeWalkthrough: The diagram shows a collection view container (pink/coral dashed border with rounded corners) containing 8 equally-sized grid cells arranged in a 2-row by 4-column layout. Each cell is a rounded rectangle with a light pink background containing a mountain/landscape icon placeholder, representing image content. The consistent spacing between cells demonstrates the grid layout pattern. Double-headed arrows on the right edge and bottom edge indicate that the collection supports both horizontal and vertical scrolling to reveal more content beyond the visible area.

content.text: Generally speaking, collections are ideal for showing image-based content.

Use the standard row or grid layout whenever possible. Collections display content by default in a horizontal row or a grid, which are simple, effective appearances that people expect. Avoid creating a custom layout that might confuse people or draw undue attention to itself.

boldSegments: Use the standard row or grid layout whenever possible.

content.text: Consider using a table instead of a collection for text. It's generally simpler and more efficient to view and digest textual information when it's displayed in a scrollable list.

boldSegments: Consider using a table instead of a collection for text.

content.text: Make it easy to choose an item. If it's too difficult to get to an item in your collection, people will get frustrated and lose interest before reaching the content they want. Use adequate padding around images to keep focus or hover effects easy to see and prevent content from overlapping.

boldSegments: Make it easy to choose an item.

content.text: Add custom interactions when necessary. By default, people can tap to select, touch and hold to edit, and swipe to scroll. If your app requires it, you can add more gestures for performing custom actions.
Consider using animations to provide feedback when people insert, delete, or reorder items. Collections support standard animations for these actions, and you can also use custom animations.

boldSegments: Consider using animations to provide feedback when people insert, delete, or reorder items.

content.text: No additional considerations for macOS, tvOS, or visionOS. Not supported in watchOS.

Use caution when making dynamic layout changes. The layout of a collection can change dynamically. Be sure any changes make sense and are easy to track. If possible, try to avoid changing the layout while people are viewing and interacting with it, unless it's in response to an explicit action.

boldSegments: Use caution when making dynamic layout changes.

platformIcons.icon: Apple Watch icon (grayed out - not supported)

content.text: To submit feedback on documentation, visit Feedback Assistant.

pages.pageSummary: This page documents the Collections UI component from Apple's Human Interface Guidelines. It defines collections as components that manage ordered content in customizable visual layouts, ideal for image-based content. The page provides five best practices covering layout choices, text alternatives, item selection UX, custom interactions, and animation feedback. Platform considerations note that watchOS is not supported, and iOS/iPadOS should use caution with dynamic layout changes. Resources link to related HIG topics and developer documentation for UICollectionView (UIKit) and NSCollectionView (AppKit).

crossPageElements.runningHeaders: Design > Guidelines > Components > Layout and organization > Collections
crossPageElements.runningFooters: Apple Developer Documentation footer with platform links, resources, and legal information

sections.title: Collections
sections.summary: Introduces the Collections component as a UI element that manages ordered content in customizable, highly visual layouts, particularly suited for image-based content.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Provides five key guidelines: use standard row/grid layouts, prefer tables for text content, ensure easy item selection with adequate padding, add custom interactions only when necessary, and use animations for insert/delete/reorder feedback.

sections.title: Platform considerations

subsections.title: iOS, iPadOS
subsections.summary: Advises caution with dynamic layout changes, recommending layouts remain stable during user interaction unless explicitly triggered.

sections.summary: Notes that Collections work across iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, and visionOS without additional considerations, but are not supported on watchOS.

sections.title: Resources

subsections.title: Related
subsections.summary: Links to Lists and tables, Image views, and Layout HIG pages.

subsections.title: Developer documentation
subsections.summary: Links to UICollectionView (UIKit) and NSCollectionView (AppKit) API documentation.

sections.summary: Provides links to related HIG topics and framework-specific developer documentation.

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document follows Apple's standard HIG page structure: it begins with a component definition and visual illustration, proceeds through best practices recommendations, addresses platform-specific considerations, and concludes with related resources and developer documentation links. The layout uses a three-column design with navigation sidebar on the left, main content in the center, and a page-level table of contents on the right.

keyTerms.definition: A UI component that manages an ordered set of content and presents it in a customizable and highly visual layout
UIKit class for displaying collections on iOS/iPadOS
AppKit class for displaying collections on macOS
A layout pattern where items are arranged in rows and columns
A horizontal layout pattern for collection items

keyFindings: Collections are ideal for displaying image-based content rather than text
Standard row or grid layouts are preferred over custom layouts to meet user expectations
Tables are more efficient than collections for displaying textual information
Adequate padding around images is essential for usability (focus/hover effects, preventing overlap)
Default collection interactions include: tap to select, touch and hold to edit, swipe to scroll
Collections support standard animations for insert, delete, and reorder operations
Collections are not supported on watchOS
Dynamic layout changes on iOS/iPadOS should only occur in response to explicit user actions

designDecisions.decision: Use collections for image content, tables for text content
designDecisions.rationale: Textual information is simpler and more efficient to view in scrollable lists

designDecisions.decision: Use standard layouts over custom layouts
designDecisions.rationale: Custom layouts may confuse users or draw undue attention away from content

designDecisions.decision: Maintain adequate padding around collection items
designDecisions.rationale: Ensures focus/hover effects are visible and prevents content overlap

designDecisions.decision: Avoid dynamic layout changes during user interaction
designDecisions.rationale: Changes should be easy to track and respond to explicit user actions
